page.title: 19Flooding
page.content: There was a major flood alert on the night of 1st February 1983, when, almost 30 years to the day since the East Coast flood disaster of 1953, in gale force winds the river level rose 1.7 metres above the predicted level. Although a sudden drop in the wind strength prevented major flooding, as the danger passed around midnight, a freak wave surge pushed the river level 2 metres above prediction, and above the 1953 levels. Gorleston lifeboat (Barham) was moved because of the high water and small boats in the river were manned to prevent them being washed up and left high and dry. Gorleston Quayside attracted a throng of onlookers, criticised by the ploice, the Stormhouse Cafe served hot drinks to emergency service workers and a nightwatchman feared to have fallen in was later found safe.
